VIII.ii.1.B.2.a
.
When an Examination Is Necessary in Claims for Undiagnosed Illness and MUCMI
When an examination is needed to decide a claim for an undiagnosed illness or MUCMI,
38 CFR 3.159(c)(4)
provides that an examination must be requested when there is
competent lay or medical evidence of a disease (or signs or symptoms of a disease) listed in
38 CFR 3.317
, and
Persian Gulf Veteran service as defined in
38 U.S.C. 1117
.
The table below describes the stages in the examination process for undiagnosed illness and MUCMI claims.
Stage
Description
1
Determine if the threshold for an examination is met by completing the following:
Determine there is competent lay or medical evidence of a disease (or signs or symptoms of a disease) listed in
38 CFR 3.317
and as outlined in
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart ii, 1.A.1.j
.
Follow the guidance in
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart ii, 1.B.1.d
to establish the Veteran has qualifying service as defined in
38 U.S.C. 1117
.
2
Determine if a Gulf War general medical examination and specialist disability benefits questionnaire (DBQ) are required or only a specialty DBQ.
3
Follow the guidance in
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart ii, 1.B.2.n
to include consideration of toxic exposure risk activity (TERA), and
request all required medical opinions based on the theories of SC raised by the Veteran or evidence of record.
Important
:  The threshold for requiring an examination is
low
.  It is lower than the standard to prove entitlement to SC, because the purpose is only to determine whether VA has a duty to assist in substantiating the claim.
References
:  For more information on
Persian Gulf Veteran service locations, see
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart ii, 1.A.1.d
determining when an examination or opinion is necessary under the duty to assist, see
M21-1, Part IV, Subpart i, 1.A
, and
sufficient medical evidence in lieu of an examination, see
M21-1, Part IV, Subpart i, 1.A.1.c
, and
M21-1, Part IV, Subpart i, 1.B.1.h
.
